description: From Middle French godet, from Dutch kodde (“piece of cylindrical wood”).

entries.meaning: (sewing) A piece of fabric inserted into a garment along a seam or cut to lengthen the free edge, and to make a garment roomier and to add a wavy edge cf. gusset.
examples: A pie-shaped godet (the most common one), is usually cut with straight grain down the center of the piece of fabric, leaving bias edges on the sides.

entries.meaning: (textiles) A roller for guiding synthetic filaments during drawing.
examples: Primary air entanglement is applied to give the yarn better cohesion and thus achieve a smoother, quieter thread path over the godets.
After the yarn guiding block a heated godet with idler roll acts as a spinning godet and thus defines spinning […] .
